user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of mutex_thread:
```c
static void *mutex_thread(void *arg)
{
	metal_mutex_t *l = arg;
	int i;

	for (i = 0; i < mutex_test_count; i++) {
		metal_mutex_acquire(l);
		usleep(1);
		metal_mutex_release(l);
	}

	return NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function mutex_thread:
static const int mutex_test_count = 1000
...
typedef struct {
	atomic_int v;
} metal_mutex_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No occurrences of the Standard Library function memcmp or any other memory-comparison call are present in the provided code fragments. The mutex_thread function only calls metal_mutex_acquire, usleep and metal_mutex_release and performs integer loop control; there are no char arrays, char pointers, string literals, or any comparisons of null-terminated strings in the shown code. The additional definitions (mutex_test_count and metal_mutex_t) contain only an integer constant and an atomic_int field, respectively — neither uses memcmp or string operations. Therefore there are no code fragments in the supplied code that need investigation for Rule 21.14. (If implementations of the called functions such as metal_mutex_acquire/release or other omitted files use memcmp on null-terminated strings, those definitions would need to be provided and investigated, but they are not part of the given code.)
